importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report reflects the most recent update on the flood situation in Mexico, indicating the ongoing impact and government response efforts as of that day.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz confirmed 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops, including Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist in rescue and relief operations.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The rains were caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises, flooding, and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply across five states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no prior meteorological signs predicting the extreme rainfall, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Mexico, heavy rains and flooding caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have led to at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing across five states, primarily affecting Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with over 280mm of rain. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to assist with rescue, food, and water distribution. Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity to affected areas, where about 263,000 users lost power. The government, under President Claudia Sheinbaum and led by CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, acknowledged the lack of prior meteorological warnings, raising concerns about Mexico’s disaster alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
